Alignment Checker

Instructions:

Use this page to ensure layouts are functioning properly, on both the front-end and within the block editor. You'll need to resize the browser, checking in particular if things that should have padding do, while things that should not do not (and that these do not extend beyond the edges of their container).

Default:

WordPress controls alignment via the theme.json's settings.layout object. Bey default, blocks are the content width (content width), but can be set to wide width (wide width) or full width (full width). All but full width honor their container's padding. So, we get…

…root-level normal inner blocks are this width (and respect padding),

root-level wide inner blocks respect padding and are this width (and respect padding),

and root-level full inner blocks are this width.

Default Nested:

You can nest blocks within blocks, so…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

…normal inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

full inner blocks are this width.

and full inner blocks nested within groups are this width.

You can also set them to wide width, so…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

…normal inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

full inner blocks are this width.

and full inner blocks nested within groups are this width.

And, you can set them to full width, so…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

…normal inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

full inner blocks are this width.

and full inner blocks nested within groups are this width.

Custom Padding and Width:

If you want to set the padding internally (e.g. 100px), too, you can manually apply it, so…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

…normal inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

full inner blocks are this width.

and full inner blocks nested within groups are this width.

Or, you can set padding to 0px, so…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

…normal inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks nested within groups are this width,

full inner blocks are this width.

and full inner blocks nested within groups are this width.

You can also customize inner block widths (e.g. 500px/800px), which could mean…

…normal inner blocks are this width,

wide inner blocks are this width,

and full inner blocks are this width.

Lastly, you can leave the container standard but set an inner bock's width (e.g. 600px), which could mean…

a basic wide inner block is this width like usual,

but a nested block with custom wide width is width,

A normal columns block looks like…

Note that, in the event you want the columns container to have padding, you'll need to set it manually like...

…a column not pressed against the side

Spacing:

There are a few spacing sizes (for margins, padding, gaps, etc.) like…

small spacing (--wp--preset--spacing--20, matches outer container padding),

medium spacing (--wp--preset--spacing--50),

and large spacing (size --wp--preset--spacing--80).

Overrides:

There are a few resets in alignment.css that fix WordPress layout quirks. We may one day be able to get rid of these if WordPress fixes them. Each reset in alignment.css follows.

Background Color/Image Padding:

Blocks with a background color/image should not have weird padding, just default .has-global-padding

this has no extra padding...

...but you can override this override with custom padding

Cover Block Padding:

The cover block should default to .has-global-padding values, not 1em all around.

this has normal padding

Cover Blocks with Full Width Children:

Full width blocks nested within a cover block should go full width. Note this doesn't work with custom padding, since WordPress does not generate the padding rules we need to use.

this is full width

Stretched Inner Blocks:

Blocks set to stretch don't stretch their immediate children; the parent is technically stretched, but since its children are not, background colors and such are not properly full height.

this stretches full height

Nested Full Width Blocks:

An .alignfull block within a .has-global-padding container should not use 0px negative margins; otherwise, it's not full width, but instead has padding equal to .has-global-padding values.

this is full width...

...even with custom padding values.

Root-Level Block Margins:

WordPress adds a margin top equal to theme.json.styles.spacing.blockGap to blocks. You can set this block spacing to 0px (or any other value) on a block and it will conveniently apply to all that block's children; but, since root-level blocks don't have a containing block, the only way to set space between root-level blocks to 0px is to manually apply it to each block individually. That's quite a pain!

Use Global Padding:

WordPress adds a convoluted set of rules that removes the effects of global padding in many cases, so we re-apply it ourselves.
